content.raw:
It would be nice to have at least a basic box in this PR as well, so users who are often changing context are not caught by surprise when opening an empty window and it is suddenly populated with plugins which may not even be available then.

I looked a bit into how to detect changes and it looks like there is not a single API call which allows this; we will need to detect each kind of change. So I think we can go with a dialog that always opens on close whether or not there are changes, how does that sound?

content.raw:
To summarize the current options:

1. Add `<save_on_exit>` option and set it to `false` here (disabled).
    * Pros: Easier to implement, non-intrusive change.
    * Cons: It's transparent to the user, someone can save unintentionally the last changes (although the user needs to explicitly activate the option).
1. Add dialog window detecting all changes in position, size, and widget state (e.g.: user camera pose).
    1. Comparing the entire logical state of all widgets
        * Pros: More conservative, as users won't be surprised with saved changes the next time they start their application.
        * Cons: Could be a bit annoying to have a dialog window every time that we interact with some widget; our API doesn't fully support the comparison of the entire logical state so it might be harder to implement.
    1. Comparing plain XML configurations
        * More conservative, as users won't be surprised with saved changes the next time they start their application.
        * Cons: Could be a bit annoying to have a dialog window every time that we interact with some widget; the low level comparison can conclude that two configurations are different due to spacing or other non-logical differences.

Do we have consensus? I'm leaning towards option (1).

  2. Add dialog window detecting all changes in position, size, and widget state (e.g.: user camera pose).
    1. Comparing the entire logical state of all widgets
      • Pros: More conservative, as users won't be surprised with saved changes the next time they start their application.
      • Cons: Could be a bit annoying to have a dialog window every time that we interact with some widget; our API doesn't fully support the comparison of the entire logical state so it might be harder to implement.
    2. Comparing plain XML configurations
      • More conservative, as users won't be surprised with saved changes the next time they start their application.
      • Cons: Could be a bit annoying to have a dialog window every time that we interact with some widget; the low level comparison can conclude that two configurations are different due to spacing or other non-logical differences.

Do we have consensus? I'm leaning towards option (1).

content.raw:
Thanks for the summary!

> Could be a bit annoying to have a dialog window every time that we interact with some widget

The dialog would only come up once, when the user closes the application, right? And we could eventually add a checkbox where the user can choose to "never ask again".

I've been thinking a bit about the `<save_on_exit>` and I'm not convinced it makes sense to have it on the config file. For example, an application could ship a config file that has it turned on, and it will affect all users without them having a say or being able to easily change it. To me, that option is more in the realm of user settings than application settings, and I'm not convinced that user settings should go in the config file, but I can be convinced otherwise.

I'm leaning towards option 2.2, I'll work a bit on it now to see if it's feasible to compare XML strings.
